title: Which folk songs stir the most emotions? - Quora

response.answer_text: About twenty years ago, I was at a destination-wedding weekend for a high-school buddy on Isle of Palms, South Carolina. One night, we went to a bar in downtown Charleston. There was a band playing, and, at some point during the set, the band played the 1859 song “Dixie,” which, while a popular song in 1859, is now considered a folk song. The men with hats in the band and the crowd would doff their caps in rhythm to the “look aways” grouped in threes throughout the song. As a guy from Chicago, I was quite unsettled by this. I noticed there were no black folks in this bar, and I imagined this particular bar was one black folks knew—in one way or another—was not a bar they should go to. The song has been controversial for African-Americans for a long time. Steve Earle, who spent his formative years in Texas and Tennessee but now lives in New York City, wrote a great song called “Mississippi, It’s Time.” In it, he sings, “Dixieland will never miss me, but I whistle that tune sometimes. / And I’ll sing it loud when the flag comes down; / Mississippi, don’t you reckon it’s time.” Earle is referring to Mississippi’s state flag still containing the Confederate battle flag within it, which put on the flag in 1894, some twenty-nine years after the end of the Civil War.

It is probably different for each individual, especially those growing up with folk music. My choices are: Blowin in the Wind - Bob Dylan California Dreaming - Mamas and Papas My Back Pages - Bob Dylan Donna Donna - Joan Baez We Shall Overcome - Pete Seeger Catch the Wind - Donovan Turn, Turn, Turn - The Byrds (Pete Seeger) The Times They Are A-Changin - Bob Dylan
